description: A simple, healthy, and quick side dish of boiled amaranthus leaves, a highly nutritious green vegetable. Cooked without any oil, this method relies on a technique called 'water frying' to create a flavorful, tender, and vibrant green dish that is a perfect, light accompaniment to starchy staples.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: Dodo is one of the most common and affordable leafy greens in Uganda. Cooking it without oil is a standard, healthy practice in many homes, making it a vital source of vitamins and minerals. It is a quick 'relish' prepared to balance out a meal centered around Posho, Matoke, or Rice. Its quick cooking time makes it a go-to vegetable for busy families.

ingredients.name: Fresh Dodo (Amaranthus) Leaves
ingredients.notes: About 8-10 cups, washed thoroughly and chopped

steps.instruction: Add the chopped dodo leaves to the pot. It will seem like a lot, but it will wilt down significantly.
. Bring to a simmer over medium heat.
Add some cut onions into the greens.
Sprinkle the salt over the leaves. Cover the pot with a lid and let it cook for 2-3 minutes.
Uncover and stir the dodo. It will have wilted and released its own water, creating a natural cooking liquid.

cooking_indicators.visual: The leaves have reduced in volume by about 70% and turned a vibrant, dark green.

steps.instruction: Continue to cook uncovered, stirring occasionally, for another 3-5 minutes until the dodo is tender and the excess liquid has reduced. Be careful not to overcook it into mush.

cooking_indicators.texture: The stems should be tender, and the leaves should be soft but not slimy.

steps.instruction: Taste and adjust salt if needed. Serve immediately.

serving_suggestions: Served as a side dish alongside a staple carbohydrate like Posho (Ugali), Matoke, or Rice, and a source of protein like beans, groundnut sauce, or meat stew. It adds a fresh, green element to the meal.
